name: Collisions
what: This subtopic covers applying conservation principles to different collision types, analysing sticky collisions where objects combine, explosive collisions where objects separate, and comparing elastic versus inelastic collisions through energy calculations.
why: Understanding collision physics explains vehicle safety design, sports equipment performance and subatomic particle behaviour. It allows you to predict outcomes of interactions and design systems that safely absorb or transfer energy.

items.title: I can solve sticky collision problems where objects combine after impact
items.what: In sticky collisions, objects join together after impact and move with a common final velocity. Total momentum is conserved: m‚ÇÅu‚ÇÅ + m‚ÇÇu‚ÇÇ = (m‚ÇÅ + m‚ÇÇ)v.
items.why: Sticky collisions model many real scenarios including train coupling, tackled players in sports, and projectiles embedding in targets. These collisions are always inelastic.
items.example: A 200 g toy train at 1.22 m/s is hit by 150 g plasticine at 2.45 m/s. Combined system moves at v = (0.2 √ó 1.22 + 0.15 √ó 2.45)/0.35 = 1.75 m/s

items.title: I can solve explosive collision problems where objects separate from rest
items.what: In explosive collisions, a single object breaks into separate parts. Initial momentum (often zero) equals the sum of final momenta of all parts.
items.why: Explosive collisions explain recoil when firing projectiles, rocket propulsion, and nuclear decay. Understanding them allows calculation of recoil velocities and energy distributions.
items.example: A 59 kg cyclist at 5 m/s throws a 0.5 kg ball forward at 10 m/s. Cyclist's new velocity: (59.5 √ó 5) = (0.5 √ó 10) + 59v, giving v = 4.96 m/s

items.title: I can compare forces in collisions using impulse and force-time graphs
items.what: For the same momentum change, longer collision time means smaller average force. Force-time graphs with equal areas (impulse) but different peaks show different maximum forces.
items.why: This principle explains why airbags and padding reduce injury. Extending collision time reduces peak force, even though the momentum change remains the same.
items.example: Two crash tests with impulse 100,000 N¬∑s: Car A peaks at 3000 kN over 50 ms, Car B peaks at 2500 kN over 60 ms. Car B has the better crumple zone

items.title: I can apply momentum conservation to problems with objects initially at rest
items.what: When one object is initially stationary, momentum conservation simplifies to m‚ÇÅu‚ÇÅ = m‚ÇÅv‚ÇÅ + m‚ÇÇv‚ÇÇ. The initially moving object transfers momentum to the stationary one.
items.why: Many practical collision scenarios involve stationary targets, from billiard balls to particle accelerators. This simplified equation makes calculations more manageable.
items.example: An 85.7 kg hockey player at rest hits a 154 g puck to 22.5 m/s north. Player's recoil velocity: 0 = 0.154 √ó 22.5 + 85.7v, giving v = 0.0404 m/s south

items.title: I can verify momentum conservation experimentally using before and after measurements
items.what: To verify momentum conservation, calculate total momentum before collision (Œ£mu) and after collision (Œ£mv). If equal within experimental uncertainty, momentum is conserved.
items.why: Experimental verification confirms theoretical predictions and helps identify external forces that might violate momentum conservation, such as friction or magnetic forces.
